Component Details
Programming Language Python 3.7
GPU 1 x Tesla K80 (2496 CUDA cores)
Processor 1 x single core hyperthreaded Xeon Processor @2.3GHz
RAM 13 GB RAM
Storage 108 GB Runtime HDD
Operating System Linux Kernel
Libraries Pandas, NumPy, Matplotlib, TensorFlow, Keras, KerasTuner
S3.T1.4.caption: Table 1: Experimental setup for conducting this research
references: Table 1 provides an overview of the technologies and tools used in implementing and experimenting with our DL models. Figure 1 illustrates the comprehensive framework of the MCDFN model, designed for enhanced demand forecasting. It begins with raw data extraction from a point of sale (POS) system or ERP, focusing on date and sales information. The data preprocessing phase includes several critical steps: date feature extraction, which breaks down date information into granular components such as year, week, day of the month, and month; cyclic feature encoding, where these components are transformed using sine and cosine functions to capture seasonal patterns and periodicity; and the inclusion of a binary feature to indicate holidays, accounting for irregular demand spikes. Subsequently, the data is normalized to standardize the input range, an essential step for model performance and convergence. The dataset is then partitioned into training, validation, and test sets, ensuring a robust model training and evaluation process. Sliding windows of time series data are generated to create input sequences for the NN, enabling the model to learn from temporal patterns.

S3.E1.table: month_sin=sin⁡(month×2⋅πmax(month))month_sinmonth⋅2𝜋max(month)\text{month\_sin}=\sin\left(\text{month}\times\frac{2\cdot\pi}{\text{max(month% )}}\right)month_sin = roman_sin ( month × divide start_ARG 2 ⋅ italic_π end_ARG start_ARG max(month) end_ARG ) (1)
references: Product demand exhibits seasonality, being lower at the beginning and end of each year and peaking in the middle. To represent this, the following DateTime features are extracted: â€˜Day of Month,â€™ â€˜Week,â€™ â€˜Month,â€™ and â€˜Yearâ€™. We incorporated the conversion of the DateTime feature into cyclical features to handle the periodic nature of time series data more effectively. This conversion is crucial for capturing the seasonal patterns inherent in the data, which traditional linear models might fail to identify adequately. The transformation process generates sine and cosine signals for various time-based components, such as timestamp, month, day, week, and year. This approach ensures that the periodicity is represented in a form that machine learning models can interpret more accurately. â€˜Day of Monthâ€™ and â€˜Monthâ€™ features are transformed into cyclic features using equations 1, 2, 3, and 4.

The bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) model represents a pivotal component in our predictive modeling pipeline, tailored specifically for demand forecasting. This structure aligns with the temporal nature of the forecasting task, where each input sequence spans multiple time steps, with 10 features characterizing each time point. The model architecture incorporates a BiLSTM layer of 192Ã—21922192\times 2192 Ã— 2 units strategically chosen to leverage both forward and backward temporal information during sequence processing. Within this layer, the number of LSTM units is dynamically determined through hyperparameter tuning facilitated by the Keras Tuner library. BiLSTM utilizes equations 10 and 11 as forward and backward passes.
Forward LSTM:

The Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model architecture employed in this study comprises multiple layers designed to extract relevant features from temporal sequences. The model begins with a Conv1D layer comprising 64 filters and kernel size 1 to capture local patterns within the input sequences. Subsequently, an AveragePooling1D layer is applied to down-sample the feature maps, effectively reducing computational complexity while preserving essential information. Following the pooling operation, the feature maps are flattened into a 1D vector using the Flatten layer. The equations involved related to the convolution and pooling operations are shown in equations 12 and 13.
Convolution operation:

The recurrent neural network (RNN) model architecture used in our study begins with an input layer tailored to the shape of our data, followed by a SimpleRNN layer. This RNN layerâ€™s units are determined through hyperparameter tuning, allowing values between 32 and 512 in increments of 32, with the â€˜tanhâ€™ activation function effectively capturing sequential dependencies. The RNN model uses equation 14 as the forward pass.

The input layer of an MLP receives the input vector ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}bold_x. For each hidden layer lğ‘™litalic_l (where l=1,2,â€¦,Lğ‘™12â€¦ğ¿l=1,2,\ldots,Litalic_l = 1 , 2 , â€¦ , italic_L with Lğ¿Litalic_L being the number of hidden layers), the output ğ¡(l)superscriptğ¡ğ‘™\mathbf{h}^{(l)}bold_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is computed using equation 15.

Here, ğ¡(0)superscriptğ¡0\mathbf{h}^{(0)}bold_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the input vector ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}bold_x, ğ–(l)superscriptğ–ğ‘™\mathbf{W}^{(l)}bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the weight matrix for layer lğ‘™litalic_l, ğ›(l)superscriptğ›ğ‘™\mathbf{b}^{(l)}bold_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the bias vector for layer lğ‘™litalic_l, and Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ is an activation function (e.g., ReLU, sigmoid, tanh). The output layer produces the final output vector ğ²ğ²\mathbf{y}bold_y using equation 16.

A GRU consists of two gates: a reset gate and an update gate. These gates control the flow of information and help the network retain long-term dependencies while mitigating the vanishing gradient problem. The equations governing the GRU are shown in equations 17, 18, 19, and 20.
Update Gate (ztsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘¡z_{t}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) determines the amount of past information to carry forward to the future (equation 17).

Here, Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ is the sigmoid activation function, Wzsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘§W_{z}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Uzsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘§U_{z}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are weight matrices for the update gate, xtsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the input at time tğ‘¡titalic_t, htâˆ’1subscriptâ„ğ‘¡1h_{t-1}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the hidden state from the previous time step, and bzsubscriptğ‘ğ‘§b_{z}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the bias term for the update gate. The reset gate (rtsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘¡r_{t}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) determines how much past information can be forgotten (equation 18).

Here, Wrsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘ŸW_{r}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ursubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘ŸU_{r}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are weight matrices for the reset gate, and brsubscriptğ‘ğ‘Ÿb_{r}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the bias term for the reset gate. Candidate activation (h~tsubscript~â„ğ‘¡\tilde{h}_{t}over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) computes the candidateâ€™s hidden state, which is a potential update for the hidden state (equation 19).

The bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) model represents a pivotal component in our predictive modeling pipeline, tailored specifically for demand forecasting. This structure aligns with the temporal nature of the forecasting task, where each input sequence spans multiple time steps, with 10 features characterizing each time point. The model architecture incorporates a BiLSTM layer of 192Ã—21922192\times 2192 Ã— 2 units strategically chosen to leverage both forward and backward temporal information during sequence processing. Within this layer, the number of LSTM units is dynamically determined through hyperparameter tuning facilitated by the Keras Tuner library. BiLSTM utilizes equations 10 and 11 as forward and backward passes.
Forward LSTM:

The Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model architecture employed in this study comprises multiple layers designed to extract relevant features from temporal sequences. The model begins with a Conv1D layer comprising 64 filters and kernel size 1 to capture local patterns within the input sequences. Subsequently, an AveragePooling1D layer is applied to down-sample the feature maps, effectively reducing computational complexity while preserving essential information. Following the pooling operation, the feature maps are flattened into a 1D vector using the Flatten layer. The equations involved related to the convolution and pooling operations are shown in equations 12 and 13.

S4.T4.4.1.caption: Table 4: 10 fold cross-validated paired t-test between MCDFN and the other models
references: The p-value is calculated using the t-distribution to determine the probability of observing the t-statistic under the null hypothesis. The significance level (Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±) is set to 0.05. Table 4 shows the t-values and p-values for the MSE, MAE, and MAPE comparisons between the MCDFN model and various baseline models. The p-values in Table 4 indicate that all comparisons between the MCDFN model and other baseline models are statistically significant at the Î±=0.05ğ›¼0.05\alpha=0.05italic_Î± = 0.05 level for all three metrics (MSE, MAE, and MAPE). This suggests that the performance of the MCDFN model is significantly different from the baseline models across all considered metrics. The MCDFN model consistently shows significant improvements over the other models regarding MSE, MAE, and MAPE. Vanilla LSTM and CNN models, in particular, show the highest t-values, indicating large performance differences compared to the MCDFN model.
